instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Hi guys.

I have this board that was liquid damaged and someone just cleaned it and left me small traces to follow for repair. When i got it was overheating <CHIP>U8295</CHIP> which i replaced just to see but the same issue again. I measured all contact and it came to be a full short on pin 5 and 6 on <CHIP>U8295</CHIP>. Followed the line couldn't find the short but i injected voltage and the short was removed and now diode mode reading in the line is 0.112 tested with 2 different meters. With injected voltage now doesn't show any short but with external power supply shows 0.081amps pull. Any suggestions please?

Thanks :cool:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Which voltages do you get on the board?
5V, or 20V on USB-C meter?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
And nothing else?
Please, post some voltages/signals from power on sequence...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: I'll update tomorrow probably was very busy today. Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> - 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> - 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> - 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH3V3</SIGNAL> - 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_HS_TPAD</SIGNAL> - 12.6v


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.1v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0v
 Just stuck at 20v on usb-c meter

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Please, do NOT waste time checking voltages in the same power rail.
Do you really think the voltage will change after miliohm resistors???

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: Hi. Getting back to this old issue. Found a short on L2950 goes on the pin 2 side. I injected 0.9volts it's overheating the <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>... next step?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: Also i'm getting 20v on all ports when plugged in with the usb tester.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Which is the exact vale of that short (ohm scale)?
Did you compare with good board?
If really low, then you need to remove <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Yes after removing the <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> short is gone. If i get from another board will it work please? 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: There is a separate TBT ROM chip, not sure if <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> has internal firmware board dependant.
